they were founded in 1979 by the same

it became clear that there were

from
change and trade and somehow

is useful yeah what was your approach to

case begins before they adopted the

that food banks received is donated
locally but some amount is donated to

of that feeding America had to figure
out which food banks descended to they
were very very concerned about fairness
so they wanted to make sure that they
weren't unduly privileged in one food
bank over another and that they were
trying to send the food where there was
the largest perceived need so they had
calculated these perceived need metrics
called goal factors and goal pounds a
target amount of food you know number of
pounds of foods delivered each food bank
and then they were ordering the the food
banks according to these metrics and
then as donations were offered they
would they would call a food bank and
say you know we have an offer of this
many pounds of chicken would you like it
and the food bank would get the offer
and they'd have maybe four or six hours
to decide whether to take it and if they
said yes they'd be responsible for
paying transport going and picking it up
and then then storing and distributing
it but if they said no feeding America
would say okay fair enough they'd go
call the next food bank but they would
treat it as if the food bank had said
yes hmm and it seems a little strange
right so the reasoning is for the sake
of fairness you don't want to ever make
it the case that some food bank that has
some incentive to sort of wait to try
and and stay at the top of the list
until they get some very specific thing
they need so instead of feeding America
was trying to make sure that every food
bank had you know enough shots that did
each individual food type but they were
rationing offers rather than the actual
donation if you said you didn't need an
offer they inferred you know that maybe
you just don't have as much food demand
the system was very much push based and
they weren't learning anything about the
food banks actual demands other than
perhaps a little bit of information
about what they didn't need yeah said
can us the the the case introduces a
term that I found a little bit ironic
food rich you know in the context of
food banks can you explain a little bit
about the food rich versus the food poor
and how that played into the allocation
system
yes this was something that I knew
nothing about when we started as well
and it largely had to do with the
following which is food banks have a
wide range of ways of trying to persuade
owners to give food and feeding America
at the time gave probably about 20 to 25
percent of all the food that they
received and the difficulty in terms of
both the efficiency and the fairness of
the system was that there were some
parts of the country in some particular
food banks that were just very
successful at finding other types of
food and other amounts of food and food
rich refers to those food banks those
areas the country which had a very wide
supply of other food that they could
cash and the difficulty that feeding
America had was they didn't really know
what you had or how much you had so they
were essentially feeling a little bit
blind as to how much food they should be
giving to them now some of this involves
local distributors local retailers but
sometimes it just involved personal
contact skills of the individual food
bank directors but it meant that there
was a sort of a big unknown inequity in
the system that really was the backdrop
to our committee meeting there was also
incidentally the problem of transitory
demand changes so it might be that you
have to turn down a big donation of
yogurt this week because your
refrigerators were filled up with milk
yesterday but next week you'd be very
happy to have a lot of yogurt and so
even if your food poor you might still
have to turn down a donation that you
otherwise might want one of the biggest
problems for food redistribution and the
United States is spoilage and some
spoilage is implicit because a lot of
donations only come close to expiration
dates but there's a considerable amount
of spoilage that comes from the fact
that food banks may not have enough
refrigeration so if you give them
something that needs refrigeration a
very valuable piece of food will just go
to waste
do they take umbrage if somebody doesn't
want to take something that they're
planning to donate that's a terrific
question actually it's that was one of
the relearning experiences for me which
was I realized that feeding America has
essentially two constituents one are the
obvious food banks but the second
constituent are the donors and they're
very concerned with donor relations and
there are sort of two parts to
that one was they would often twist the
arms of food banks to take food that
maybe they didn't really want and that
was to keep the donors happy and that
was part of the reason why they would
penalize food banks if they actually
turned down food the second thing which
I think turned out to be much more
important than any of us realized is
that feeding America was so aware of
these relationships that often they
would turn down donations rather than
offend the donor because the one thing
that donors do not want is for a
truckload of food to be sitting under
dock for two or three days one of the
difficulties with the old system as
Scott outlined is that they would offer
to the person at the top of the list the
person at the top of the list would have
six hours to decide whether they wanted
to take it whether they had a truck that
could get there in time and what it
meant was that feeding America don'
offer to a relatively small number of
people before the donor would get upset
and what it meant was at times they
would turn down donations that otherwise
could have gone to feed the hungry so
the task force let's turn to that for a
second Candace I'm going to stick with
you for a moment here as you were there
at the beginning what was the intent of
the task force and what was the dynamic
like because it sounded like there was a
pretty good mix of people around that

combination of food bank directors very
carefully selected to include both very
large food banks but also some of the
smaller ones it had members of the
feeding America staff and it had four
faculty members from the university I
think at the beginning when we mesh
there was a sense that what feeding
America wanted to do was tweak and tweak
could involve the following which is
they would say let's never offer
potatoes to Idaho because Idaho has
plenty of potatoes or maybe we should
not give as much food to people that
have a regional distributor somewhere
nearby so the sense was that we would
stick to the push system rather than
anything that looked like a pull system
and the reason for that was the typical
reason why not for profits use push
systems which is
they fear that if they let people choose
they'll just take everything so as a
result they would decide what an
individual food bank wanted and went
from there
the dynamic of the group was wonderful I
mean I think one of the amazing things
about this committee which is not true
of all committees one spends time on it
was essentially the length of time we
got to listen to each other I think if
it has turned out to be a success the
reason it has been a success was largely
because of the willingness not of the

but actually the practitioners to listen
to the academics because this was a long
way removed from anything that they
imagined they would do when we started
mm-hmm that makes a lot of sense so
there were a lot of ideas I guess that
surfaced in the context of the
conversations and you decided to go with
this market-based solution Scott can you
explain the difference between the push
versus the pull approach sure my
understanding is they came reasonably
quickly to this idea that if only there
were some way to give the food banks
choice then a lot of the problems of the
push system would go away right they
didn't know which food banks wanted
which food they didn't know which were
food rich in food poor overall they
didn't know anything about transitory
demand if only the food banks could just
tell you this would be great and
moreover if they had a liquid market
right if they had some way of learning
which food banks needed which donations
both they could figure out which
donations to solicit more of and maybe
they could even place some of those
donations they were otherwise having
trouble placing the key to all of this
seemed to be choice you had to somehow
learn the food banks preferences but of
course you can't just sort of say as
Candice said just tell us your
preferences take what you want because
you still don't have enough to give
everyone everything right you need to
somehow figure out some way of balancing
fairly between the different food banks
what they realized was that they could
switch to a market like system if food
banks are bidding this can reveal their
demand but now there's a different
problem of course you don't want them
bidding in real cash because if anything
the food banks that that have a little
bit more money maybe are the ones who
are more resourced you don't want to
create inequality by using a cash market
instead they created sort of an internal
currency called shares every day there'd
be a spot market in donations the food
banks would bid shares and
for each donation you know the food bank
that bid the most would be assigned that
donation they would go pick it up and
they would pay their shares into the
center of the system the collected
shares from the day and the end of the
day would be redistributed back out to
the food banks in proportion to those
same goal factors the need estimates
from before now hearing inequality
smooths itself you know you save up
shares you you bid on the things you
want and then at the end of the day if
you sort of get money back from the
system in proportion to how much
everyone else spent yeah this has this
miraculous property that if you're a
food bank who didn't buy anything today
then you're much more able to buy
something tomorrow and at the same time
we learned demand right you learned the
food banks relative demands for
different types of food and you can even
hope to learn which food is most
valuable for the system and how much so
it makes perfect sense
but can us I'm guessing it wasn't like
immediately embraced by everybody in the
room what was some of the reactions to
this when it was proposed I would say
not even close we've all been in
meetings where while the other side is

Lance's being exchanged between some of

and you know I think it came down not to
a philosophical disagreement with the
notion that choice could be valuable
because part of the reason why this was
introduced realistically is because they
were very frustrated with the old system
they were being given food that they
already had they thought other people
were benefiting relative to them there
was an enormous amount frustration but
it was still quite a distance from what
they thought we would do and I think it
came down to actually a much more
general point at the moment about
markets which is I think there's a
sentiment among many people that markets
benefit too strong at the expense of the
weak and I think in the context of this
the strong meant the big more heavily

Los Angeles Chicago New York and I think
there was a sentiment that anything that
we put in place would benefit them
relative to a very understaffed place a
for example West Virginia that really
doesn't have the staff to manage these
things so it was only after talking
really for a year that we managed to
persuade the participants
what they see as potential inequities
could actually be resolved in a way that

you one of the things that I really love

different stages that might cause your

than they are in the future on top of

think of ranging from having the market

had credits so you could go a little bit

small food banks could band together and

for bigger stopgaps
there was a committee that would be set

that's good so I mentioned this takes

at what happened in the system and we

so first of all there's immediate

know pasta cereal things that are

more shares than things like chips and

so some of them buy lots more of the low

some of Candice's work tries to

Wow
the most extraordinary fact I think is

wow that's amazing
Candice are you still involved with the

has been enormous ly successful at

the amount of food they're sourcing is

many of the donations which used to

market and one of the things that
feeding America has done over the last
decade has become a purchasing agent it
uses its buying power and then sells on

of inequities because some food banks
are better able to raise funds than
others so I'm trying to do a bit of work
on - I'm also trying to do another thing
which is I think one of the biggest
remaining problems with charitable food

level which is the poor tend to come to

those institutions are not the most

is something that would be really
